I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 

 
1. 
to Nepal for the Kathmandu Valley Water Supply Improvement Project.1
 
 
The project will complement past and ongoing efforts to improve access, efficiency, and 
2. 
reliability of water supply services to the residents of Kathmandu Valley.2
 While ongoing projects 
are  investing  in  source  augmentation,  construction  of  Melamchi  tunnel  and  water  treatment 
plant, the project will focus on distribution of water from the treatment plant to consumers, and 
improvement  of  efficiency  and  service  delivery.  The  project  will  also  support  and  consolidate 
institutional  development  and  improvement  of  governance  in  the  water  sector  in  Kathmandu 
Valley. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

 
A. 

Rationale 

3. 
Current  status.  Kathmandu  Valley  is  characterized  by  high  population growth  of  more 
than 6% per annum and high population density of more than 10,000 per square kilometer.3 The 
population  of  Kathmandu  Valley  is  estimated  at  2.72  million  in  2011  and  3.50  million  in  2016. 
Rapid and largely unplanned urban growth, lack of sustainable water sources, and inadequate 
past investments have resulted in poor availability and quality of drinking water.4 Moreover, poor 
access  to  water  has  caused  increased  disease  incidence,  health  risks,  and  associated 
economic burdens that disproportionately impact the poor and vulnerable.5
 
 
Development  partnership.  Earlier  efforts  of  the  Government  of  Nepal  and  various 
4. 
development partners to improve water supply services in Kathmandu Valley have now started 
to  achieve  the  desired  results.6  The  progress  of  the  Melamchi  Water  Supply  Project  and  the 
Kathmandu Valley Water Services Sector Development Program7
 has been encouraging in the 
last  2  years  despite  frequent  political  disturbances  and  institutional  weaknesses.  These  loans 
were adversely affected from 2000 to 2006, when several development partners withdrew due 
to the then-prevailing volatile sociopolitical situation and internal conflict in the country leading to

reduction  of  the  project  financing  by  $133  million  from  the  estimated  $464  million. 8
 
Consequently,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  approved  a  major  change  in  scope  and 
implementation arrangements of these loans in February 2008 to prioritize the use of available 
funds  for  source  augmentation,  i.e.,  Melamchi  tunnel.  The  Japan  International  Cooperation 
Agency (JICA), in a parallel financed project, is providing support for a water treatment plant to 
utilize water from Melamchi tunnel. To fully utilize the benefits of ongoing projects, investments 
in the project are necessary and timely. 
 
Lessons.  The  project  was  developed  using  lessons  from  previous  ADB  interventions, 
5. 
and country assistance program evaluation9
 which pointed to the need for strategic clarity and 
prioritization of urban infrastructure investments. The implementation arrangements have been 
kept simple with a focus on using the institutional arrangements created under previous projects 
to  ensure  continued  capacity  building  and  sustainability.  An  important  lesson  from  earlier 
projects  was  to  give  importance  to  rehabilitation  of  networks  along  with  creation  of  assets. 
Accordingly,  the  project  will  focus  on  reducing  nonrevenue  water  (NRW)  and  improving  the 
existing network. Another lesson is to involve stakeholders; the project has  provided adequate 
resources for participation of various stakeholders. Further, as learned from earlier projects, civil 
works packages have been kept sufficiently large to attract qualified international bidders. 
 
6. 
Focus  on  improvement  of  efficiencies  and  service  delivery.  The  project  will  utilize 
the district metering areas10 approach to improve efficiencies and reduce NRW from the level of 
more  than  50%  to  less  than  20%  in  areas  where  distribution  network  improvement  will  be 
carried out. With the completion of Melamchi tunnel, Kathmandu Valley will receive an additional 
170 million liters per day (MLD) of water, while the current average availability is only 100 MLD 
against a demand of 367 MLD.11
 The project will introduce 24-hour water supply in at least 10% 
of the service area, which will be selected on techno-economic considerations. The project will 
introduce a comprehensive asset management plan to minimize the lifecycle costs of procuring 
and  maintaining  assets.  The  project  will  adopt  contracts  with  adequate  provisions  to  monitor 
NRW reduction, and develop geographical information system (GIS) to maximize benefits.  
 
7. 
Context in  country  programming. The project is consistent with ADB’s Nepal country 
partnership  strategy,12  which  aims  to  support  Nepal’s  peace  and  development  aspirations  by 
promoting the following four pillars: (i) broad-based and inclusive economic growth, (ii) inclusive 
social  development,  (iii)  governance  and  capacity  building,  and  (iv)  climate  change  adaptation 
and environmental sustainability. The project fits into the priority sector “water supply and other 
municipal  infrastructure  and  services”  identified  in  the  country  partnership  strategy  and  will 
support the country’s peace and development through improved access to basic services. The 
project is included in the country operations business plan of Nepal.13
 
 
 

                                                
8  The total project cost was estimated as $464 million at 2000 prices, which was to be funded by the Government of 
Nepal and a consortium of development partners: ADB, $120 million; the World Bank, $80 million; Japan Bank for 
International  Cooperation,  $52  million;  JICA,  $18  million;  Norwegian  Agency  for  International  Cooperation, 
$28 million; Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency, $25 million; the Nordic Development Fund, 
$9  million;  and  the  Organization  of  the  Petroleum  Exporting  Countries  Fund  for  International  Development,  
$14 million. The World Bank withdrew in 2002, the Norwegian Agency for International Cooperation in 2005, and 
the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency in 2006 causing a shortfall of $133 million. 

9   ADB. 2009. Country Assistance Program Evaluation for Nepal. Manila.

meter to measure input water quantity and consumer meters to measure consumption, the difference is used for 
assessing NRW in the district metering area. 

11 The availability of water varies widely ranging from 70 MLD in the dry season to 140 MLD in the wet season. 
12 ADB. 2009. Country Partnership Strategy: Nepal, 2010–2012. Manila.

B. 

Impact and Outcome 

 

3 

8. 
The expected impact of the project is sustainable water supply services for residents of 
Kathmandu  Valley.  The  expected  outcome  is  improved  access,  efficiency,  and  reliability  of 
water  supply  services  to  the  residents  of  Kathmandu  Valley  including  poor  women  and  men. 
The project will prioritize underserved areas and poor sections of the population in Kathmandu 
Valley. Piped water through individual household connection will relieve women of the drudgery 
of  managing  water,  thereby  giving  them  more  time  for  social  and  economically  productive 
activities.  The  impact  and  outcome  of  the  project  will  be  closely  linked  with  the  success  of 
ongoing projects. 
 
C. 

Outputs 

The  project  will  follow  the  investment  priorities  identified  in  the  government’s  capital 
  for  annual  investments  in  water  supply 

9. 
investment  and  asset  management  program,  2010,14
infrastructure in Kathmandu Valley. The project outputs will include the following: 
 

(i) 

(ii) 

Output 1: Rehabilitation and expansion of the water supply system. This will 
include  (a)  a  bulk  distribution  system  (BDS),  distribution  network  improvement 
(DNI),  and  service  reservoirs;  (b)  provision  of  individual  connections  to  citizens, 
especially  the  poor  and households  headed  by women;  (c)  provision  of 24-hour 
water supply in at least 10% of the service area; and (d) efficiency improvement 
in  water  supply  through  provision  of  bulk  and  individual  meters,  reduction  of 
NRW,  and  reduction  of  energy  losses  in  electromechanical  machinery.  This 
output  will  have  two  distinct  geographic  areas.  DNI  areas  will  be  the  areas  in 
which both BDS and DNI works will be implemented and non-DNI areas15
 will be 
the areas in which only BDS works will be implemented. 
 
Output  2:  Support for operating  and financial  improvements,  and  capacity 
building. This will include (a) capacity building; improvement of governance; and 
achievement  of  time-bound  targets  as  per  the  agreed  business  plan  of 
Kathmandu  Upatyaka  Khanepani  Limited  (KUKL),  the  Kathmandu  Valley  Water 
Supply  Management  Board  (KVWSMB),  and  the  Water  Supply  Tariff  Fixation 
Commission;16
 (b) operationalization of the NRW assessment and reduction plan;  
(c)  operationalization  of  the  asset  management  plan;  (d)  updating  of  the  water 
supply GIS database; (e) improvement of KUKL’s responsiveness to customers; 
(f)  community  participation  and  public  education  for  health,  hygiene,  and 
behavior  change  in,  for  example,  water  conservation,  good  water  management 
practices  including  3Rs  (reduce,  reuse,  and  recycle),  rainwater  harvesting;  
(g)  a  gender  equality  and  social  inclusion  action  plan;  (h)  monitoring  and 
evaluation; and (i) support for project management. This output will continue and 
enhance support being provided under the ongoing loans.

The  government  has  requested  a  loan  in  various  currencies  equivalent  to  $80  million 
from ADB’s Special Funds resources to finance the project. The loan will have a 32-year term, 
including  a  grace  period  of  8  years,  an  interest  charge  of  1.0%  per  annum  during  the  grace

consultants, recurrent costs, transportation, insurance, and financing charges.

DUE DILIGENCE 

15.       Nonrevenue  water  assessment  and  reduction  plan.  The  water  supply  system  in 
Kathmandu  Valley  is  characterized  by  high  NRW.19
  Lack  of  proper  metering  compounds  the 
problem  of  NRW  assessment.  To  ensure  sustainability  of  the  project  operations,  KUKL  will 
implement  a  comprehensive  NRW  assessment  and  reduction  plan  with  specific  time-bound 
targets. The project will facilitate integration of the NRW reduction approach in DNI packages as 
part of output 1 and will support KUKL, under output 2, to implement the NRW assessment and 
reduction plan. 
 
16. 
Asset  management  plan.  Currently, KUKL lacks focus on timely repair and preventive 
maintenance  of  assets.  To  ensure  sustainability  of  project  operations,  KUKL  will  implement  a 
comprehensive asset management plan focusing on an integrated approach to repair, maintain, 
rehabilitate, and replace assets with the objective of minimizing lifecycle costs. The project will 
help KUKL implement the asset management plan.

components, which will be useful even without water from Melamchi tunnel. The government will 
monitor progress of Melamchi tunnel to ensure completion with minimum delay.

B. 

Economic and Financial 

 

7 

20. 
Economic  analysis.  The  estimated  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  is  18.1%; 
the net present value is $20.1 million. The EIRR is higher than the economic opportunity cost of 
capital  estimated  at  12.0%  indicating  sufficiently  high  economic  return.  The  result  is  robust 
against  downside  risks,  as  brought  out  by  sensitivity  analysis  carried  out  with  (i)  capital  costs 
increased  by  10%,  (ii)  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  costs  increased  by  10%,  and  
(iii)  benefits  reduced  by  10%.  The  EIRR  varies  from  14.8%  to  18.1%;  the  most  sensitive  risk 
factor is a delay in completing Melamchi tunnel.21
 
 
21. 
Financial  analysis.  The estimated financial internal rate of return (FIRR) is 7.46%; the 
net present value is $29.37 million. The FIRR is higher than the weighted average cost of capital 
estimated at 3.5% indicating reasonable financial return. The result is robust against downside 
risks, as brought out by sensitivity analysis carried out with (i) capital costs increased by 10%, 
(ii)  O&M  costs  increased  by  10%,  and  (iii)  revenues  reduced  by  10%.  The  FIRR  varies  from 
6.64% to 7.46%; the most sensitive risk factors are an increase in capital costs and decrease in 
revenues.  Based  on  the  proposed  tariff  schedule,  monthly  water  bills  will  account  for  0.7%  to 
1.4%  of  monthly  income,  which  is  significantly  below  the  5%  ratio  generally  assumed  to 
determine  household  affordability.  The  project  is  financially  viable  and  affordable  for  all, 
including poor households.22
 
 
Financial  sustainability.  The  capacity  building  and  public–private  partnership  (CBP) 
22. 
team,  mobilized  in  KUKL  under  the  ongoing  Kathmandu  Valley  Water  Services  Sector 
Development  Program,  will  support  operating  and  financial  improvements  of  KUKL.  The  CBP 
team  will  prepare  a  business  plan  for  KUKL  for  long-term  financial  sustainability  focusing  on  
(i) rationalization of tariffs to recover O&M costs, depreciation, and financing costs in a phased 
manner;  (ii)  improvement  of  collection  efficiency;  (iii)  recovery  of  arrears  with  adequate 
provisioning for bad debts; (iv) adoption of prudential financial norms; and (v) computerization of 
operations and financial management. The operationalization of the asset management plan will 
help  KUKL  achieve  higher  operating  efficiencies,  and  better  financial  performance.  The 
government  will  ensure  that  KUKL,  with  support  from  the  CBP  team,  undertakes  preparation, 
adoption,  and  effective  implementation  of  the  business  plan.  Further,  the  government  will 
ensure that the tariffs are revised every year to achieve financial sustainability. 
 
C. 

Governance 

23. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  and  PID.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary  measures 
are described in the PAM (footnote 17). Risk assessment was made with the help of three tools 
specifically  developed  for  Nepal:  (i)  peace  filter  for  design  and  implementation  of  project,  (ii) 
governance risk assessment tool, (iii) disaster and climate change risks screening tool.23
 Based 
on these assessments, some of the mitigation measures incorporated in project design are to (i) 
establish a mechanism for regular voluntary disclosure of project-related information to citizens; 
(ii) develop and utilize a system of e-procurement; (iii) develop and update a project website to 
enhance  transparency  in  project  implementation,  procurement,  and  safeguards;  and  (iv) 
establish a grievance redress mechanism to ensure quick and effective relief.

KUKL’s  institutional  arrangements.  KUKL’s  institutional  structure,  designed  at  the

D. 

Poverty and Social 

25. 
The  project  is  classified  as  effective  gender  mainstreaming.  A  poverty  and  social 
analysis  has  been  completed 24   and  the  project  gives  priority  to  connecting  all  poor  and 
households  headed  by  women  to  the  piped  water  supply  system  in  the  project  area.  The 
government  and  KUKL  will  reform  the  current  water  connections  policy  (2008)  to  facilitate 
individual  water  connections  to  the  poor,  socially  excluded,  and  households  headed  by 
women.25  Connection  fees  will  be  reduced  for  poor  households  under  the  project.  A  gender 
equality and social inclusion26 action plan was prepared with clear targets, responsibilities, and 
resource  allocation.  The  project  has  also  prepared  a  community  awareness  and  participation 
plan27
  to  involve  key  stakeholders  for  widespread,  ongoing,  and  meaningful  participation.  PID 
will  implement  the  gender  equality  and  social  inclusion  and  community  awareness  and 
participation  plan,  with  support  from  the  community  awareness  and  participation  consultant 
recruited under the project. 
 
E. 

Safeguards 

26. 
Social  safeguards. The project is classified as category B for involuntary resettlement 
and  category  C for  indigenous  peoples  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement 
(2009). 28     The  project  does  not  require  any  land  acquisition.  The  impacts  are  limited  to 
temporary  disruption  of  business  activities,  and  temporary  shifting  of  vendors  and  hawkers 
during  construction  works  within  the  right-of-way  for  the  BDS,  and  DNI  works.  A  resettlement 
plan,29  including  the  grievance  redress  mechanism,  was  prepared  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Safeguard  Policy  Statement.  A  resettlement  framework 30   was  prepared  to  address  small 
components  to  be  defined  through  detailed  design  after  approval  by  the  ADB  Board  of 
Directors.31
 Temporary impacts will be limited and compensation for lost income will be provided 
to  those  affected  as  per  the  resettlement  plan.  Land  required  for  service  reservoirs  for  the 
project was acquired under the ongoing Melamchi Water Supply Project. All land is to be made 
ready for construction before the first disbursement. No adverse impacts on indigenous peoples 
are  anticipated  as  the  project  focuses  on  rehabilitating  the  existing  water  supply  network  in 
urban areas. Meaningful and widespread consultations will continue with all communities in the 
project area.

IV. 

ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 

30. 
The  government  and  KUKL  have  assured  ADB  that  implementation  of  the  project  will 
conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures, 
safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as  described  in  the 
PAM (footnote 17) and loan documents. The government and KUKL have agreed with ADB on 
certain  covenants  for  the  project,  which  are  set  forth  in  the  loan  and  project  agreements.  As 
conditions to the disbursement, the following conditions will have to be met (i) KUKL will have 
approved  audited  financial  accounts  from  FY2008  up  to  FY2010;  (ii)  KUKL  will  have  finalized 
and  approved  a  long-term  business  plan;  (iii)  the  government  will  have  paid  all  compensation 
under  the  ongoing  Melamchi  Water  Supply  Project  and  cleared  all  required  land  of  all 
encroachers  in  the  area,  in  the  manner  consistent  with  the  agreed  relevant  resettlement  plan; 
(iv)  the  government  will  have  signed  a  subsidiary  financing  agreement  in  form  and  substance 
acceptable to ADB; and (v) the government will have revised the water connection policy to be 
more  pro-poor,  including  reduction  of  the  water  connection  fees  and  a  waiver  for  the 
requirement of a certificate of building completion. 
 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

31. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  in  various 
currencies  equivalent  to  SDR50,482,000  to  Nepal  for  the  Kathmandu  Valley  Water  Supply 
Improvement Project from ADB’s Special Funds resources with an interest charge at the rate of 
1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 32 years, 
including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft loan and project agreements presented to the Board.
